stories.text:
#!/bin/sh
   # 1.sh: search/dump
   test $# -gt 1||exec echo "usage: $0 cfg-file [section]";
   x=$1;shift;y=$(echo "$@"|sed 's/ /./g');sed -En ]/p;}" $x 
   
   #!/bin/sh
   # 2.sh: delete/remove
   test $# -gt 2||exec echo "usage: $0 cfg-file section-name";
   x=$1;shift;y=$(echo "$@"|sed 's/ /./g');sed -iE ]/d;}" $x 

   #!/bin/sh
   # 3.sh: add/insert
   test $# -eq 2||exec echo usage: $0 cfg-file line-no \< section-file
   (echo $2;echo a;sed '1{/^[1-9]*/d;}';echo .;echo wq)|ed $1
Objective: Without needing non-standard programs or large scripting laguages, manage and edit long. relatively complex configuration files that are divided into sections

Example:

      # 1.cfg: indented config file
      # sections are separated with a left-justified control character such as ^L and/or ^K
      # note for learners: ^L is inserted by typing Ctrl-V followed by Ctrl-L
   ^L
      # SECTION W-a1
      foo
   ^L
      # SECTION X-b1
      bar
   ^L
      # SECTION Y-c1
      baz
   ^L
      # SECTION Z-d1
      qux
Dump all sections

    1.sh 1.cfg \# SECTION
The line numbers for all lines will be printed. This can be useful for adding/inserting sections. The output can also be edited to work as an ed script.

Dump sections W-a1 and Y-c1

    1.sh 1.cfg \# SECTION [WY]-[ac]1
The line number for the section header will be printed. This number, e.g., N-1, can be useful for adding/inserting sections.

Dump section Y-c1 to a file for editing

    1.sh 1.cfg \# SECTION Y-ac1  > edit.txt
Delete section Y-c1

    2.sh 1.cfg \# SECTION Y-c1
Insert edited/new section into config file

    3.sh 1.cfg 9 < edit.txt
9 is the line number where we want the section inserted
stories.title: Manage/edit large, complex configuration files with sed and ed
